article:
'Thermosynthesis' is a theoretical mechanism proposed by Anthonie Muller for
biological use of the free energy in a temperature gradient to drive
energetically uphill anabolic reactions. {{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller year = 1983 title = Thermoelectric
 | energy conversion could be an energy source of living organisms
 | journal = Physics Letters A volume = 96 issue = 6 pages=319â321 doi =
 | 10.1016/0375-9601(83)90189-5
|bibcode = 1983PhLA...96..319M }} {{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller year = 1993 title = A mechanism for
 | thermosynthesis based on a thermotropic phase transition in an asymmetric
 | biomembrane journal = Physiological Chemistry and Physics and Medical NMR
 | volume = 115 pages=95â111
}} It makes use of this thermal gradient, or the dissipative structure of
convection in this gradient, to drive a microscopic heat engine that performs
condensation reactions. Thus negative entropy is generated. The components of
the biological thermosynthesis machinery concern progenitors of today's ATP
synthase, which functions according to the binding change mechanism, driven by
chemiosmosis. Resembling primitive free energy generating physico-chemical
processes based on temperature-dependent adsorption to inorganic materials such
as clay, {{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller and Dirk Schulze-Makuch title = Sorption heat
 | engines: simple inanimate negative entropy generators journal = Physica A
 | volume = 362 year=2006 issue = 2 pages=369â381 doi
 | =10.1016/j.physa.2005.12.003
|arxiv = physics/0507173 |bibcode = 2006PhyA..362..369M }} this simple
type of energy conversion is proposed to have sustained the origin of life,
{{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller year = 1995 title = Were the first organisms
 | heat engines? A new model for biogenesis and the early evolution of
 | biological energy conversion journal = Progress in Biophysics and Molecular
 | Biology volume = 63 pages=193â231 doi = 10.1016/0079-6107(95)00004-7 pmid =
 | 7542789 issue = 2
}} {{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller year = 1996 title = The thermosynthesis model
 | for the origin of life and the emergence of regulation by Ca 2+
 | journal = Essays in Biochemistry volume = 31 pages=103â119 pmid = 9078461
}} {{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller and Dirk Schulze-Makuch title = Thermal
 | energy and the origin of life journal = Origins of Life and Evolution of
 | Biospheres volume = 36 issue = 2 year=2006 pages=77â189 pmid = 16642267 doi
 | =10.1007/s11084-005-9003-4
|bibcode = 2006OLEB...36..177M }} {{cite journal
 | author = M. Kaufmann title = On the free energy that drove primordial
 | anabolism journal = International Journal of Molecular Sciences volume = 10
 | year=2009 pages=1853â1871 doi =10.3390/ijms10041853 pmid = 19468343 issue = 4
 | pmc = 2680651
}} including the emergence of the RNA World. {{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller year = 2005 title = Thermosynthesis as energy
 | source for the RNA World: a model for the bioenergetics of the origin of life
 | journal = Biosystems volume = 82 pages=93â102 doi
 | =10.1016/j.biosystems.2005.06.003 pmid = 16024164 issue = 1
}} For this RNA World it gives a model that describes the stepwise
acquisition of the set of transfer RNAs that sustains the Genetic code. The
phylogenetic tree of extant transfer RNAs is consistent with the idea.
{{cite journal
 | author = F.J. Sun and G. Caetano-Anolles year = 2008 title = The origin and
 | evolution of tRNA inferred from phylogenetic analysis of structure journal =
 | Journal of Molecular Evolution volume = 66 pages=21â35 doi=10.1007/s00239-007-9050-
 | 8 pmid = 18058157 issue = 1
}}

Thermosynthesis may still occur in some terrestrial {{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller year = 1985 title = Thermosynthesis by
 | biomembranes: energy gain from cyclic temperature changes journal =
 | Journal of Theoretical Biology volume = 115 pages=319â321 pmid=3162066
 | doi=10.1016/S0022-5193(85)80202-2
}} and extraterrestrial {{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller year = 1996 title = Life on Mars? journal =
 | Nature pmid = 8600375 volume = 380 issue = 6570 pages=100 doi =
 | 10.1038/380100b0
|bibcode = 1996Natur.380..100M }} {{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller year = 2001 title = The thermosynthesis model
 | for the origin of life: implications for Solar System exploration journal =
 | Marsbugs volume = 8 issue= 15 pages=3â6
 | url=http://www.lyon.edu/projects/marsbugs/2001/20010423.pdf
}}  {{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller year = 2003 title = Finding extraterrestrial
 | organisms living on thermosynthesis journal = Astrobiology volume = 3
 | pages=555â564 doi =10.1089/153110703322610645 pmid = 14678664 issue = 3
|bibcode = 2003AsBio...3..555M }} environments. However, no organisms are
known at present that use thermosynthesis as a source of energy, although it is
possible that it might occur in extraterrestrial environments where no light is
available, such as on the subsurface ocean that may exist on the moon
Europa. Thermosynthesis also permits a simple model for the origin of
photosynthesis. {{cite arxiv
 | author= Anthonie W.J. Muller eprint= physics/0501050 title = Photosystem 0, a
 | proposed ancestral photosystem without reducing power that uses metastable
 | light-induced dipoles for ATP synthesis year = 2005 class= physics.bio-ph
}} It has moreover been used to explain the origin of animals by
symbiogenesis of benthic sessile thermosynthesizers at hydrothermal vents during
the Snowball Earths of the Precambrian. {{cite journal
 | author = Anthonie W.J. Muller year = 2009 title = Emergence of animals during
 | Snowball Earths from biological heat engines in the thermal gradient above
 | submarine hydrothermal vents journal = Origins of Life and Evolution of
 | Biospheres pmid = 19468860 volume = 39 issue = 3-4 pmc = 2691805
 | pages=321â322 doi =10.1007/s11084-009-9164-7
|bibcode = 2009OLEB...39..179. }} {{cite arxiv
 | author= Anthonie W.J. Muller eprint= 0811.1375 title = Emergence of animals
 | from heat engines. Part 1. Before the Snowball Earths year = 2008 class=
 | physics.bio-ph
}} {{cite journal
 | doi= 10.1038/npre.2009.3333.2 author= Anthonie W.J. Muller url=
 | http://precedings.nature.com/documents/3333/version/2 title = Animal
 | emergence during Snowball Earths by thermosynthesis in submarine hydrothermal
 | vents year = 2009 journal = Nature Precedings accessdate=2009-06-20
}} Preliminary experiments have started to attempt to isolate
thermosynthetic organisms. {{cite arxiv
 | author= Anthonie W.J. Muller eprint= physics/0604084.pdf title = A search for
 | thermosynthesis: starvation survival in thermally cycled bacteria year = 2006
}}
